'Irwin Allen Ginsberg' (; June 3, 1926 â April 5, 1997) was a Jewish American
poet and one of the leading figures of the Beat Generation in the 1950s. He
vigorously opposed militarism, economic materialism and sexual repression.
Ginsberg is best known for his epic poem "Howl", in which he denounced what he
saw as the destructive forces of capitalism and conformity in the United
States. Ginsberg, Allen (2000), Deliberate Prose: Selected Essays 1952â1995.
Foreword by Edward Sanders. New York: HarperCollinsPublishers, pp.
xxâxxi. de Grazia, Edward. (1992) [[Girls Lean Back Everywhere: The
Law of Obscenity and the Assault on Genius]]. New York: Random House, pp.
330â31.

In 1957, "Howl" attracted widespread publicity when it became the subject of an
obscenity trial, as it depicted heterosexual and homosexual sex see
Ginsberg, "Howl" pp. 13â15. at a time when sodomy laws made homosexual
acts a crime in every U.S. state. "Howl" reflected Ginsberg's own homosexuality
and his relationships with a number of men, including Peter Orlovsky, his
lifelong partner. Kramer, Jane (1968), Allen Ginsberg in America. New York:
Random House, pp.43â46, on Ginsberg's first meeting with Orlovsky and the
conditions of their "marriage." Also see, Miles, Barry (1989), Ginsberg: A
Biography. New York: Simon and Schuster, pp. 178â79, on Ginsberg's description
of sex with Orlovsky as "one of the first times that I felt open with a
boy." Judge Clayton W. Horn ruled that "Howl" was not obscene, adding,
"Would there be any freedom of press or speech if one must reduce his vocabulary
to vapid innocuous euphemisms?" de Grazia, p. 338.

Ginsberg was a practising Buddhist who studied Eastern religious disciplines
extensively. He lived modestly, buying his clothing in second-hand stores and
residing in downscale apartments in New Yorkâs East Village. One of
his most influential teachers was the Tibetan Buddhist, the Venerable ChÃ¶gyam
Trungpa, founder of the Naropa Institute, now Naropa University at Boulder,
Colorado. Barry Miles. Ginsberg: A Biography. London: Virgin Publishing Ltd
(2001), paperback, 628 pages, ISBN 0-7535-0486-3, pp. 440â44. At Trungpa's
urging, Ginsberg and poet Anne Waldman started The Jack Kerouac School of
Disembodied Poetics there in 1974. Miles, pp. 454â55.

Ginsberg took part in decades of non-violent political protest against
everything from the Vietnam War to the War on Drugs. see Ginsberg,
(Deliberate Prose), from the foreword by Edward Sanders, p. xxi. His poem
"September on Jessore Road," calling attention to the plight of Bangladeshi
refugees, exemplifies what the literary critic Helen Vendler described as
Ginsberg's tireless persistence in protesting against "imperial politics, and
persecution of the powerless." Vendler, Helen. "Books: A Lifelong Poem
Including History", The New Yorker, January 13, 1986, p. 81.

His collection The Fall of America shared the annual U.S. National Book Award
for Poetry in 1974. In 1979 he received the National Arts
Club gold medal and was inducted into the American Academy and Institute of Arts
and Letters. Miles, p. 484. Ginsberg was a Pulitzer Prize finalist in
1995 for his book Cosmopolitan Greetings: Poems 1986â1992.
